The problem with simply creating the Grand Canyon all at once at the beginning, is that the canyon cuts through sedimentary rocks. Even if God had to create the river beds in place, including the Grand Canyon, why not make the entire earth out of igneous bedrock, with the necessary top soil for the plants to grow? Why would a creator create deep layers of rock that look exactly like they have been put into place by known natural processes? The God-as-deceiver argument.
 
 As far as being formed by the receding waters of the great flood, consider this -- there is no way that any amount of flood waters could have created such a nice, neat, deep canyon through solid rock. Flood geologists suppose that the canyon was cut while the rock was still soft mud. But, as you point out Kronus, the canyon is about a mile deep in places -- you try to form any structure out of soft mud with nice straight vertical walls. It ain't gonna be done.
